misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that in Java, calling an input method like Scanner.nextInt() automatically handles the display of the prompt text ('Enter grade: ') shown in the sample run, or that the prompt is an external instruction for the user rather than a required output of the code itself.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In the Java notional machine, input (System.in) and output (System.out) are distinct, uncoupled streams. The Scanner class is designed solely to parse the input stream and does not have any functionality to write to the output stream. To achieve the behavior in the sample run, the programmer must explicitly use System.out.print() before requesting input.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output; the program fails to print the 'Enter grade: ' prompt as required. Upon execution, the program will hang silently at the input line, potentially leaving the user unaware that it is waiting for a value.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Automatic Input Prompt (believing nextInt() shows the prompt)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that reading input with Scanner.nextInt() will implicitly prompt the user (or that the prompt text is unnecessary for matching the required sample run).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, Scanner.nextInt() only attempts to parse an integer from the input stream; it does not print anything to the console. Any required prompt text (e.g., "Enter grade: ") must be explicitly printed with System.out.print/println before the input read. As written, the program waits for input with no prompt, so its observable I/O order differs from the sample run even though the grade-to-letter logic is correct.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Output mismatch vs. sample run / missing prompt before input (not a compile/runtime error).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that calling an input method like y.nextInt() automatically handles the user-facing prompt requested in the problem description, or that the 'Enter grade: ' text shown in the sample run is an intrinsic part of the input operation itself.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In the Java execution model, System.in (input) and System.out (output) are independent streams. A Scanner object only reads data from the input buffer; it does not communicate expectations to the user. To display a prompt, the programmer must explicitly invoke a print method before the input method is called.
